meanings.definition: An introductory section of a literary work.
meanings.sent1: The prolog of the story set the stage for what was to come.
meanings.sent2: The author included a prolog to provide background information for the readers.
meanings.sent3: The prolog was like a sneak peek into the world of the book.
meanings.sent4: Her life felt like a prolog, leading up to the main adventure.
meanings.sent5: The prolog painted a vivid picture of the story's setting.

meanings.definition: A preliminary or introductory event or action.
meanings.sent1: The meeting served as a prolog to the negotiations that followed.
meanings.sent2: The prolog of the play introduced the main characters and their conflicts.
meanings.sent3: The prolog to the party was a game to break the ice.
meanings.sent4: The prolog of the movie was like the calm before the storm.
meanings.sent5: The prolog of the race got everyone excited for the competition.

meanings.sent1: She will prolog her speech with a brief history of the topic.
meanings.sent2: Before starting the presentation, he decided to prolog with a personal anecdote.
meanings.sent3: He liked to prolog his jokes with a funny story to set the mood.
meanings.sent4: The teacher would always prolog the lesson with a thought-provoking question.
meanings.sent5: To prolog the event, they played a short video highlighting the organization's mission.
